docs.snippet: The House of Representatives defied a threatened presidential veto, voting to lift four-decade-old restrictions on travel to Cuba. Lawmakers also voted to lift the caps on money that can be sent to Cuban households. The 227-to-188 vote to open tra...
docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives defied a threatened presidential veto, voting to lift four-decade-old restrictions on travel to Cuba. Lawmakers also voted to lift the caps on money that can be sent to Cuban households. The 227-to-188 vote to open travel to Cuba was not as decisive as a similar vote last year, a reflection of anger over the Castro government's recent crackdown on political dissidents. There has traditionally been support in the House for lifting the embargoes on trade and travel to Cuba, but moves in that direction have been thwarted either by the Senate or the White House.
docs.abstract: House of Representatives defies threat of veto by George W Bush and votes to ease travel restrictions to Cuba and to lift caps on money that can be sent to Cuban households (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: House Votes To Lift Cuba Travel Ban

docs.snippet: A judge prohibited about 20 top executives from five of Argentina's biggest banks from leaving the country, a court official and the police said yesterday. The officials of the Argentine operations of Citibank, Banco Sudameris, Banco Galicia, Flee...
docs.lead_paragraph: A judge prohibited about 20 top executives from five of Argentina's biggest banks from leaving the country, a court official and the police said yesterday. The officials of the Argentine operations of Citibank, Banco Sudameris, Banco Galicia, FleetBoston Financial's BankBoston and Scotiabank Quilmes were ordered to remain in Argentina while the judge investigates accusations of illegal capital flight. The order does not mean any of the bankers are accused of illegal activity, the court official said. Officials at Citibank, Banco Galicia and BankBoston declined to comment, while spokesmen at Banco Sudameris and Scotiabank Quilmes were not immediately available for comment.
docs.abstract: Judge orders officials of Argentine operations of Citibank, Banco Sudameris, Banco Galicia, Fleet Boston Financial's BankBoston and Scotiabank Quilmes to remain in Argentina while he investigates accusations of illegal capital flight; order does not mean any of bankers are accused of illegal activity (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Travel Ban For Bankers

docs.snippet: American Jewish leaders have called off their travel boycott of Mexico, saying they are satisfied there has been "a decided reversal" of the attitude reflected by Mexico in voting last November in favor of a United Nations resolution linking Zioni...
docs.lead_paragraph: American Jewish leaders have called off their travel boycott of Mexico, saying they are satisfied there has been "a decided reversal" of the attitude reflected by Mexico in voting last November in favor of a United Nations resolution linking Zionism with racism.
docs.abstract: Conf of Presidents of Major Amer Jewish Orgns calls off its travel boycott of Mexico, saying it is satisfied there has been 'decided reversal' of attitude by Mexico since its Nov vote in UN for resolution equating Zionism with racism; conf, which represents 32 Jewish groups, says it has decided to recommend that relations between Amer Jewish groups and Mexico be 'fully normalized,' after reviewing developments since vote; notes it was reassured by recent statements by new Foreign Min Alfonso Garcia Robles; conf chmn Rabbi Alexander M Schindler comments (M)

headline.main: U.S. Jews End Ban on Travel to Mexico
